title.rendered: Tergu, Church of Nostra Signora di Tergu (Our Lady of Tergu)

content.rendered:
Many of the island’s Romanesque churches have intertwined their history with that of various monastic orders active in Sardinia in the Middle Ages, such as the church of Nostra Signora (also known simply as Santa Maria), annexed to the most important Benedictine monastery in Anglona, seat of the Cassinese priory. This relationship is attested in the sources of 1122, where it is listed as a possession of the Cassinese monks, although the precise date of the donation is not ascertained. An ancient document, called “Libellus Judicum Turritanorum”, describes it as being founded by Mariano I de Làcon Gunale, Judge of Torres between 1065 and 1082. In two inscription fragments we find news of work on the monastery in the second half of the 12th century: it is likely that the façade was rebuilt at this time. 

In the 15th century, the monastery was incorporated into the Archdiocese of Torres. The creation of the entrance portal and part of the remaining structures of the monastic complex date back to this phase. The structural and decorative analysis of the façade refers to Pisan models from the second half of the 12th century. The plan of the church is in the form of a “commissa” cross, a probable later modification of an original single-nave hall with a north-eastern apse. To the north is a square-bore bell tower. The covering of the transept arms is barrel-vaulted, although the opening to the hall is with an ogive arch.

The first order of the façade, of which the pediment is now lost, is based on large blind arcades. The central arch contains an architraved portal surmounted by a drainage arch alternating volcanic and limestone ashlars. The second order is marked by a four-lobed oculus.  

We now turn away from the church of Nostra Signora di Tergu, after greeting it with sincere respect.

title.rendered: Suelli, Church of San Pietro (Saint Peter)

content.rendered:
In the Middle Ages, many towns and villages saw the emergence of a continuity of use between the ancient Roman forum and the main square, intended as a market place and progressively enriched with buildings and public functions. In many towns in Sardinia too, the square has the ancient function of a beating heart, such as the centre of Suelli. 

In the Middle Ages, the ‘villa’ of Suellis was part of the Giudicato of Cagliari and was included in the curatorìa of Trexenta. According to the ‘Provinciale Romanum’, Suellis was a suffragan see of the archdiocese of Cagliari. It is not by chance, therefore, that here, in the centre of the village, we find the parish church of San Pietro Apostolo, the sanctuary dedicated to San Giorgio and the small church of Carmine. 

The main church communicates with the sanctuary through the sacristy and the lower cell of the bell tower. We have no documentary sources that inform us about the date of construction of the cathedral of Suelli. The first mention of the title dates back to 1121-29, when the bishop Pietro Pintori, with the endorsement of the judge of Cagliari Mariano Torchitorio II de Làcon-Gunale, made public the donations made by private individuals for this church.

From a formal analysis of the still existing structures – the work of Tuscan craftsmen active in Sardinia for the first time – it is possible to infer its rebuilding in the first half of the 13th century.  The building was then restructured in the 16th century, with the creation of side chapels and the bell tower. 

Only a few parts of the exterior masonry are preserved from the original structure: the base of the façade, part of a row of portal arches, a jamb capital decorated with false leaves and stems and the outlines of the wall arches. The floor plan of the Romanesque building presumably had a nave and two side aisles with a south-eastern apse, later replaced by a Late Gothic presbytery. 

The façade was characterised by five mirrors and three portals. A single lancet window, in the keystone of which a frontal eagle clawing a hare is carved, opens on the north side. The lower cell of the square belfry is another persistence of the Romanesque building. 

We leave Suelli, taking with us the strong sensation of having made an exciting journey into the past.

title.rendered: Massama, Oratorio delle Anime (Holy Souls Oratory)

content.rendered:
The history of mankind has often followed the routes marked out by communication routes, in their heterogeneous conformation, ranging from simple paths to the imposing imperial roads of the Roman era. This relationship is translated, for example in the place names, which retain the verbal trace. This seems to be the case of Massama, the ancient Marsima, a place-name that, according to some scholars, derives from the location of the settlement along the ‘via maxima’, the road that in Roman times connected Tharros and Forum Traiani (today Fordongianus). 

In Massama, we find the Oratorio delle Anime, a building of early medieval origin – as attested by the ancient dedication to San Nicola, bishop of Mira – with later interventions in the Romanesque period (the first half of the 13th century). 

The church has a cruciform ground plan, but in the place of the eastern arm there is a large apse with a distinctive horseshoe shape.  An octagonal lantern is inserted at the intersection of the arms. The bell tower is made of earthenware tiles in contrast to the rest of the church built of stone: this could be an indication that it was built at a later date. 

The façade has a sloping profile, with a smooth face and no windows. The essential entrance portal opens here. A little above the portal, a row of ashlars marked by cavities created to accommodate the typical ceramic basins can be seen. 

We thus bid farewell to the church of the Oratory of the Souls, trusting that our visit may have helped to alleviate their stay in Purgatory.

title.rendered: Onanì, Church of San Pietro Apostolo (Saint Peter Apostle)

content.rendered:
We have often noted the close relationship between many of the island’s Romanesque buildings and the rural landscape. This is no coincidence: this relationship expresses the need of the time to put places dedicated to work in the countryside under divine protection, as well as to offer precious points of reference and support to medieval travellers. 

The church of San Pietro Apostolo di Onanì, right in the heart of Sardinia, is right in the group of these buildings characterised by a radical relationship with the natural landscape. We have no documentary evidence of the construction of the church, made of granite worked in small ashlars, but we can date its construction to the 12th century. There is a strong affinity with similar small churches on the islands of Elba and Corsica, also made of granite. 

The plan of the building has a single nave, with a south-eastern apse, with a single-light window in the centre surmounted by a cruciform opening, similar to the one on the façade, where we find the portal with a raised archway and a schist architrave. The slopes converge towards a large bell gable. The external roof, made of schist slabs, is noteworthy. 

We conclude our visit by taking a last admiring look at the church of San Pedro Apóstol and the splendid Barbàgia landscape that surrounds it.

title.rendered: Bonòrva, Church of San Lorenzo di Rebèccu (Saint Lawrence)

content.rendered:
The church of San Lorenzo is located on a hill, in total harmony with the space that welcomes it, and is situated near Rebeccu, the mysterious and legendary medieval village, which is now abandoned. We have no specific information on its construction, but the structural analysis of the building and the discovery, in 1831, of a lead seal of Barisone II, judge of Torres between 1147 and 1186, allow us to chronologically place its construction in the second half of the 12th century. 

The façade has a bell gable and an architraved portal surmounted by a lunette. Wide corner pilasters surround the base of the gables, characterised by the presence of five small arches. In both gables, a cruciform light illuminates the hall.

The floor plan has a single nave with an oriented apse. The original facing is made of limestone ashlars with basalt inserts: a clear hint of two-colouring. 

At the beginning of the 19th century, the church underwent a partial demolition, becoming a quarry for the construction of the Rebeccu parish church. In 1982, the south side and the wooden roof were restored. 

As we make our way towards the next stage, a farewell to this little jewel, perfectly set among the hills, leaves us with the reverberation of its beautiful forms.

title.rendered: Bànari, Church of Santa Maria di Cea

content.rendered:
Romanesque churches offer many opportunities for encounters and discoveries, as they acted like catalysts for cultural and religious energies, among which, the monastic dimension must certainly be included. Eloquent proof of this relationship is the country church of Santa Maria di Cea, (in Sardinian: Nostra Sennora de Se) originally “di Sève”, an ancient small town located in the fertile valley crossed by the permanent stream of Badu de Corte, about 6 km from Bànari.

It was originally a place of worship linked to the Vallombrosans, a community of Benedictine monks founded by Saint John Gualbert in 1039. These monks owe their name to the forest of Vallombrosa in Tuscany, an area they managed from the 11th century until 1866, when their ecclesiastical property was confiscated by the Kingdom of Italy.

The monastic complex of Santa Maria di Cea, dating back to the second half of the 12th century, was definitively confirmed to this Congregation in the early 15th century and then elevated to an abbey in 1474. Today, we can still admire the Romanesque church, the enclosed inner courtyard, which until the second half of the last century, was used for animal breeding and agriculture, along with some hermitages, buildings where hermits retired to live. 

The façade, made of squared limestone ashlars, is divided about half way up by a slightly projecting string-course cornice. The lower register shows a series of capitals with floral motifs. At the top is a remarkable bell gable with a semicircular span, as if to watch over the testimonies of devotion offered by pilgrims and monks of the past.

The building has a single-nave floor plan, which can be accessed through two entrances: a side entrance – the so-called ‘Holy Door’ – and the main entrance for the faithful.

title.rendered: Dragon Itinerary

content.rendered:
From Dolianova to Samassi

Dolianova, S. Pantaleo

Serdiana, Santa Maria di Sibiola

Ussana, S. Saturnino

Samassi, San Gemiliano

The name of this itinerary pays tribute to the dragon, a mythological figure present in many medieval sacred buildings. We encounter some sculptural manifestations of it in the church of San Pantaleo in Dolianova, an important example of architecture built between the 12th and 13th centuries, inside of which important medieval frescoes are preserved. 

We then walk towards the church of Santa Maria di Sibiòla in Serdiana (12th century), characterised by its building typology with two apses side by side. 

A similar plan also awaits us in the church of San Saturnino di Ussana, also dating back to the 12th century. 

A visit to the church of San Gentiliano in Samassi (13th century), built on a hill known as ‘Su Cunventu’, a place-name that may be interpreted as evidence of an ancient monastic appurtenance, concludes this itinerary.

title.rendered: Itinerary of the Relics

content.rendered:
from Usellus to Gesico

Usellus, Santa Lucia

Sardara, S. Gregorio

Villamar, S. Pietro

Gesico, Santa Maria

The name chosen to designate this itinerary draws attention to the theme of the search for relics, which so marked medieval history. It is therefore no coincidence that our journey begins with the church of Santa Lucia in Usellus (12th-13th century), which houses a stone basin, possibly belonging to a medieval reliquary. 

The next stop is the church of San Gregorio at Sardara, dating from the 14th century and characterised by a refined building technique. 

We then move on to Villamar, where the church of San Pietro awaits us, also dating from the 13th century. 

We end our journey with a visit to the church of Santa Maria in Gesico, which, thanks to an epigraph, can be dated back to 1305.

title.rendered: Itinerary of the Cross

content.rendered:
From Santa Giusta to Bidonì

Santa Giusta, Santa Giusta
Cabras, S. Giovanni di Sinis
Fordongianus, S. Lussorio
Solarussa, San Gregorio Magno
San Vero Milis, Santa Sofia
Milis, San Paolo
Santu Lussurgiu, S. Leonardo di Siete Fuentes
Ghilarza, S. Pietro di Zuri
Bidoni, S. Pietro

The reference to the cross that marks this itinerary is so eloquent that it requires no further explanation. The journey begins with the former cathedral of Santa Giusta (first half of the 12th century), remarkable for many reasons, not least for the use of a construction technique that can be traced back to that adopted in the construction sites of the cathedral of Santa Maria in Pisa, Tuscany.
We then head on to Cabras, on the Sinis peninsula, to enjoy a visit to the church of San Giovanni. Located along the road leading to the excavations of the city of Tharros, its construction dates back to the Byzantine era (6th-7th centuries) with a subsequent extension in the early Romanesque period (11th century).
Our route then takes us to the church of San Lussorio at Fordongiànus (late 11th – early 12th century), characterised by the use of a local reddish volcanic stone.
We move on to Solarussa to admire the essential beauty of the church of San Gregorio Magno.
Now it’s the turn of the church of Santa Sofia in San Vero Milis, which is waiting to tell us about its extensive and articulated building history.
The next stop is the church of Milis, dedicated to San Paolo, with a spectacular façade built in opus bìcroma, alternating rows of limestone and basalt.
The next stop is the church of San Leonardo di Siete Fuentes in Santu Lussurgiu, whose name already expresses its deep connection with the springs in the area.
From there we go on to admire the church of San Pietro di Zuri in Ghilarza, which bears witness to a daring rescue operation: in the 1920s, the church and the entire village, which stood along the banks of the Tirso, were moved further upstream to avoid being submerged following the creation of the Lake Omodeo reservoir.
We end our journey with a visit to the church of San Pietro in Bidonì, a significant example of the so-called “minor” Romanesque style.

title.rendered: Itinerary of the Metal

content.rendered:
From Uta to Tratalìas

The name of this itinerary evokes the millenary relationship that Sardinia has with mining and metallurgical practices. And if there is a territory that, more than any other, can offer eloquent testimony of this, it is certainly the Sulcis-lglesiente.

Among the Romanesque churches that characterise this territory, we would like to point out the church of Santa Maria di Uta (12th century), noteworthy for the sculptural decorations present in the corbels on the external walls.

The next stop is the church of San Platano in Villaspeciosa (12th century), which is worth a visit if only to admire its peculiar two-nave plan.
You can then head towards the west coast to visit the church of San Ranieri in Villamassargia, now dedicated to the Madonna del Pilar, which still has its late Romanesque façade dating from 1318.

Moving further inland, we finally come across the church of Santa Maria di Tratalìas, dating from between 1213 and 1282, once the seat of the Sulci diocese.

title.rendered: Zerfaliu, Church of San Giovanni Battista (St. John Baptist)

content.rendered:
The philosopher Immanuel Kant reminds us that time and space represent our existence, translating it into inner experience. Every fragment of the past bears witness to this, to the extent that memories, traditions, habits and affections coagulate in it. 

The small church of San Giovanni Battista fully responds to this reality. It is a small treasure chest dating back to the 13th century: the apsidal hall has a single nave and is lit by single-lancet windows with a cross-shaped light. 

Restoration works, carried out in 1981, uncovered a number of stone tombs, one of which is under the foundations of the building, and therefore older than the date of its construction. 

The portal is architraved and, just above the architrave, the concavities originally intended to hold the traditional ceramic basins are still visible. 

At a later stage, which cannot be chronologically defined, the church underwent an extension towards the north: the façade was extended, the small bell tower was moved and the apse was decentralised towards the south. A clear indication of this structural change can be found in the materials used for the two building phases: the well-crafted basalt and calcarenite stones belong to the first construction, while the small-sized stones to the extension. The side walls were fitted with buttresses to prevent the danger of possible collapse. 

While our minds are already searching for the next stage of our journey, our hearts linger a little longer as we bid farewell to this little architectural jewel.

title.rendered: Zeddiani, Church of the Vergine delle Grazie or Sant’Antonio da Padova (Our Lady of Graces or Saint Anthony of Padua)

content.rendered:
On our journey along the Romanesque routes in Sardinia, we have come across buildings of all kinds: simple and complex, isolated and fully integrated into the residential fabric, with a single-phase architectural history or the result of complex historical events. Rare are the buildings that entrust their identity to their essential architectural structure. This is the case of the Church of the Virgin of Graces, also known as St Anthony of Padua. 

The most plausible date of its construction is the first half of the 13th century. The structure that has come down to us was modified by a 17th-century reconstruction; the original, of which parts of the sides and the façade survive, had a single-nave hall with an east-facing apse. 

The shape of the terminal has been altered, but the outline of the gable and the basic ashlars of the bell gable remain legible. The use of sandstone blocks with basalt inserts as ornamentation, are eloquent indications of an aesthetic vocation towards two-colouring. Also on the façade there are ten ceramic basin rooms arranged in a single row, two single lancet windows with double splays and a ribbed part open on the south side, while another architraved single lancet window is on the north side.

Looking at this small church, we discover how moving simplicity can be.

title.rendered: Villaputzu, Church of San Nicola di Quirra

content.rendered:
Almost all the Romanesque churches that make up the island’s mosaic, were built using stone as a building material. But the church of San Nicola di Quirra, located near the castle of the same name, is an exception to this rule. 

Unfortunately, we do not have any documentary information on the construction of the church, but it seems plausible to place its construction between the second half of the 12th century and the beginning of the 13th. Studies have shown that the ‘Tuscan reed’ and ‘quadrature’ were used as methods of measuring the building. 

A series of small arches move the slopes of the east gable, the sides of the church and the façade, which is thus modulated into two sectors in the centre of which the portal opens. The façade culminates in a striking bell gable with an ogival opening that makes the church of San Nicola di Quirra even more fascinating. 

The single-nave hall, with an east-facing apse, is covered by a wooden roof on trusses that rest on frames decorated with engravings with geometric motifs. Two single-lancet windows open on each side and another single-lancet window opens in the apse, which is enriched by a series of small arches set on corbels also decorated with geometric motifs.

title.rendered: Usini, Church of Santa Croce (Holy Cross)

content.rendered:
In spite of the strong presence of Romanesque architecture in Sardinia, the beauty of this style never ceases to amaze travellers who come across it, either by intention or by chance. This is how we feel in the presence of the church of Santa Croce: amazed by its simple beauty. 

Also known as ‘Santa Maria del Cimitero’ or ‘Madonna de s’Ena frisca’ (of the fresh spring), the church of Santa Croce is run by the confraternity of Santa Croce, from which it derives its present name. Documentary information can be found in the ‘Condàghe di San Pietro di Silki’ (XI-XIII century), but does not provide information on the date of construction of the church, which presumably took place in two distinct moments between the end of the XIII and the XIV centuries. Its construction probably responded to the need to officiate the rites in the area where the town was expanding, in the direction of Piazza Castello. 

Of the original Romanesque church, built in limestone, with a single-nave hall and east-facing apse, all that remains is the façade and parts of the cornice, which continues horizontally on the façade to mark the pediment, and a theory of small arches on corbels. The transept and the pointed windows belong to the second building phase. A series of chapels, the sacristy and the bell tower date from later building phases. 

The sloping roofs are decorated with a series of narrow, elongated pointed arches, which are also present below the cornice. 

Simplicity and purity: this is the memory we will take with us of the church of Santa Croce.

title.rendered: Uri, Church of Nostra Signora di Paùlis (Our Lady of Paùlis)

content.rendered:
Names are treasure chests of memory. Discovering them reveals the stories that generated them, offering those who question them the precious opportunity to feel a part of them. This is what happens if we question the word ‘paùlis’ associated with the name of Nostra Signora, to whom the church is dedicated: this Sardinian term, derived from the Latin ‘paludis’, which was the original place name, still designates many places in Sardinia, a legacy of a long historical phase in which a significant part of the island’s territory was occupied by marshy and unhealthy land. 

The Abbey of Nostra Signora di Paulis was created in 1205, following a donation by the King of Torres Comita II to the Cistercian Benedictines, and remained in activity as a monastic community until the 15th century. Nostra Signora di Paulis was built along the route of a Roman road, later called ‘s’istrada de sos Padres’ because it connected this abbey to the Cistercian abbey of Santa Maria di Corte in the territory of Sindia. 

The limestone structure shows clear signs of the work of the Cistercian masters operating in Sardinia between the 12th and 13th centuries. Of the complex, subject to progressive degradation and restored several times, there are remains of the cloister and some rooms of the convent adjacent to the abbey, visible around the main building. 

The crux commissa plan of the church had a nave and two aisles marked by arches on pillars, with a slightly protruding transept. The square apse and two chapels, one on each side, were grafted onto the transept. The rooms were covered with barrel vaults. On the south side of the oriented apse there was a Latin cross window, while on the east side of the choir there was a mullioned window surmounted by a single lancet window (a reference to the Trinity) in which there was a tile with a Greek cross. 

We leave this building with regret for the losses that have marked it.

title.rendered: Solarussa, Church of San Gregorio

content.rendered:
The church of San Gregorio, characterised by a very simple structure and a refined stonework technique, has a floor and a basin dating back to the early Roman period, perhaps belonging to a thermal building. But that is not all: a second wrought floor is also visible, belonging to the Romanesque church and the foundations are related to a pre-existing early medieval church with a single-nave hall. 

The formal analysis of the building and the reference to the place-name ‘Solagrussa or Solarossa’ in two acts of the ‘Condaghe di Santa Maria di Bonarcado’, dated 12th and 13th centuries, help us to frame its construction in the second half of the 12th century. The mastery of ashlar-working techniques and the stylistic essentiality suggest the possibility that the church was built by the same workers who built the church of Santa Maria di Bonarcado between 1110 and 1147. The structure has a longitudinal plan and an east-facing apse. 

The façade features a portal with architrave, bichromatic lunette and rounded centring. The top of the façade was probably decorated with a ceramic basin, now lost, of which traces can be seen. A second portal gives this place of worship a unique and suggestive appearance. 

We leave the church of San Gregorio taking its precious simplicity with us.

title.rendered: Sindìa, Chiesa di Santa Maria di Corte

content.rendered:
On our journey to discover Romanesque churches, water can be a valuable guide in directing our steps. This is how we arrive at the church of Santa Maria di Corte, built on the rural site of “Cabu àbbas” or “Caput aquae”, whose name derives from the numerous water sources that characterise it. The attribute ‘de Corte’, on the other hand, testifies to the origin of the church. 

From the “Libellus Judicum (Iudicum) Turritanòrum”, a 13th century chronicle in the Logudorese vernacular, we learn that the ‘judge’ of Torres, Gonario de Làcon-Gunale, met Bernard of Clairvaux during his pilgrimage to the Holy Land and on that occasion agreed to send a Cistercian monastic community to Sardinia. The commitment was fulfilled with the construction of the church and monastery in 1149. The present building was constructed around 1600. 

Stratigraphic investigations have recovered traces of the original abbey and monastic complex, which had been abandoned as early as the 15th century and then despoiled to recover building materials. 

The church had a floor plan with a nave and two aisles and a crux commissa. The transept had a quadrangular apse, which still exists, and four chapels, two on each side, covered with a barrel vault and each lit by a single lancet window. 

The transept was lit by a circular oculus in the form of a cross of light, placed in axis with the median pillar in the wall facing the two chapels.

title.rendered: Sìligo, Chiesa di Santa Maria di Mešumùndu

content.rendered:
Ancient buildings and structures are often reused or even completely dismantled in order to recover construction material for new buildings: this is the phenomenon of ‘reuse’, one of the most typical manifestations of the process of continuous transformation that characterises life and therefore also human cultures. 

The Church of St Mary of Mešumùndu is a good example of this, as it was built on the ruins of ancient Roman baths from the late imperial period.  However, the building also has other original elements, both in its layout and in the use of the opus listàtum construction technique, which consists of alternating rows of red bricks and basalt stones. The use of this masonry technique can be considered proof of the building’s Byzantine origin, as also attested by the burials found in the vicinity. 

The discovery of a 7th-century inscription provides a significant chronological date for the original structure. The identification of this church with that of Santa Maria di Bubàlis, donated to the abbey of Montecassino in 1065 by the Turret judge Torcotorio Barisone I de Làcon-Gunale, is considered certain. 

An enlargement of the structure dates back to the Judicates period, with the construction of the apses in basalt ashlars and the entradosso recessed with respect to the impost line. The use of the ‘sack’ technique in some wall sections can be traced back to the 11th century. 

The plan of the church is vaguely cruciform: the effect is obtained by the connection between four differently shaped bodies of the building and a central rotunda of greater height. A small apse opens in the east wall of the north-eastern wing; two other apses of different sizes open to the north-east and south-west. Finally, the large lights on the south-west side and the single-light window in the north room date from different periods. 

The originality of this place of worship is surprising every time you look at it.

title.rendered: Silanus, Church of Santa Sabina

content.rendered:
In the collective imagination, archaeological research is nourished by excavation, without which it would seem that the past, covered by the dust and earth that centuries and human events have deposited there, is destined, or almost condemned, to oblivion. But such an image is misleading, because in many cases the past, present and future manifest themselves in happy synchronicity, filling the landscape around them with surprising harmony. This phenomenon is most strikingly represented by the church of Santa Sabina di Silanus, built in the immediate vicinity of the nuraghe of the same name, with which it dialogues without any difficulty of language. 

The plan of the building evokes a pre-existing late-antique or Byzantine layout, modified in the 11th century. The structure has a central apsidal rotunda, covered by a sort of dome, flanked by two rectangular chambers covered in wood, also completed by apses to the east. The materials used for the construction are limestone and basalt. 

There are two portals on the west elevation, while the main one, located in the rotunda, has a simple architrave resting on the perimeter walls and is preceded by a tympanum prothyrum that forms a small room, just over two metres long, open at the front and barrel-vaulted. The wall face of the south chamber is largely a reconstruction. The upper edge of the vault of the frontal profile of the prothyrum is decorated with ashlars arranged in a long semicircle. The secondary portal, in the north chamber, is of the centred round-headed type, with jambs made of imposing basalt blocks. 

Time has made dialogue between the church and the nuraghe more intimate, thanks to the reuse of some blocks from the nuraghe itself. Still immersed in its ancient history, we salute this monument, grateful for what it has been able to tell us about itself.

title.rendered: Siamaggiore, Chiesa di San Ciriaco

content.rendered:
One of the peculiarities that characterises several rural sanctuaries in Sardinia, is the presence of peculiar structures called muristènes (or cumbessìas). These are small lodgings, built next to churches and country sanctuaries to accommodate monks and pilgrims.  

The country church of San Ciriaco is proof of this reality linked to worship. Unfortunately, in 1917 a devastating flood, caused by the Tirso river, destroyed many of the houses in the village, including the muristènes, which were never rebuilt.

The first historical attestation of the church dates back to 1282, which certifies that it was built in an earlier period, referring to an ancient rural settlement that has now disappeared. The current appearance of the church dates back to the 18th century. 

The plan of the building has a rectangular hall with two side chapels forming a pseudo transept. The walls have no decorative elements and are almost entirely plastered. The roof of the hall is made of wood. The presbytery is ennobled by the presence of an altar and a marble balustrade dated 1791, the work of the artist Battista Spazzi.

title.rendered: Serdiana, Church of Santa Maria di Sibiòla

content.rendered:
One of the elements that characterises the world of Romanesque churches, is undoubtedly the infinite play of stylistic mirrors and thematic cross-references, that transforms the whole of Sardinian Romanesque structures into a veritable pulsating and coherent architectural organism. 

The church of Santa Maria, belonging to the medieval village of Sibiòla, registered from 1215 to the end of the 16th century, belonging to the curatorìa of Dolia and belonging to the giudicato of Cagliari, is a clear testimony of this. The oldest attestation of the church’s title appears in the last inventory, dating back to 1338, regarding the property owned in Sardinia by the Vittorini of Marseille. 

The structure, with a double-nave plan, is one of the best preserved in Sardinia. The two naves are unequal, the largest being the south, and are divided by four arches on low pillars with capitals. Both naves are covered with a barrel vault, punctuated by sub-arches, which are a precious dating element: in fact, they can be compared to those present in the church of San Saturnino in Cagliari (1089-1119), which was an inspiring model for the construction of several Sardinian churches by the workers in the service of the Vittorini family. 

While the internal masonry is made of sandstone cantons, the external masonry has sub-square cantonments on the sides and in the apses, and rows of squared ashlars on the façade, between which are ashlars of various colours and the housing for the ceramic basins, now lost except for one fragment. Worthy of note, is the geometric solution followed for the rectangular arrangement of the cavities in the upper part of the façade. 

In the centre of the façade, we note the presence of an ashlar with grooves for tarsìe, now restored, which presents a radiating circle. The façade is square, circumscribed by corner pilasters; the sloping roof and the bell gable, of which only the base ashlars remain, have been lost. A small external staircase, built on the left side of the bell tower, allowed access. Nine rounded hanging arches resting on decorated corbels mark the façade, and continue along the sides with more hanging arches. 

Having paid our respects to this beautiful building, we can now resume our walk, ready for the next encounter.

title.rendered: Semèstene, Chiesa di San Nicola di Trullas

content.rendered:
A good way to approach Romanesque architecture is to interpret each building as a creative stylistic exercise, aimed at declining the Romanesque code with originality. It is with this spirit that we can set out to get to know the church of San Nicola di Trullas, one of the most beautiful and significant manifestations of this style. The papers of the ‘Condaghe di San Nicola di Trullas’ (12th-13th century) give news of its donation, datable to 1113, by the Athen family to the Camaldolese monks. The name Trullas already appears in this deed of donation and may refer to an older Byzantine domed church: in fact, the term ‘trudda’ is the Logudorese version of the Greek and Latin ‘troulla/trulla’  meaning ‘dome’. 

The construction of the Romanesque church, made with the use of limestone ashlars combined with trachyte elements, must have started after 1113. The building has a single nave, divided into two square bays separated by a sub-arch set on pilasters and covered by cross vaults. A horizontal frame divides the façade: the upper part has a series of small arches on small columns that create a false loggia, while the lower part has an architraved portal with a raised arch.

narrazione:
A good way to approach Romanesque architecture is to interpret each building as a creative stylistic exercise, aimed at declining the Romanesque code with originality.

It is with this spirit that we can set out to get to know the church of San Nicola di Trullas, one of the most beautiful and significant manifestations of this style.

The papers of the 'Condaghe di San Nicola di Trullas' (12th-13th century) give news of its donation, datable to 1113, by the Athen family to the Camaldolese monks.

The name Trullas already appears in this deed of donation and may refer to an older Byzantine domed church: in fact, the term 'trudda' is the Logudorese version of the Greek and Latin 'troulla/trulla'  meaning 'dome'. 

The construction of the Romanesque church, made with the use of limestone ashlars combined with trachyte elements, must have started after 1113.

The building has a single nave, divided into two square bays separated by a sub-arch set on pilasters and covered by cross vaults.

A horizontal frame divides the façade: the upper part has a series of small arches on small columns that create a false loggia, while the lower part has an architraved portal with a raised arch. 

The presence of valuable frescoes in the interior, dating from the first decades of the 13th century, makes a visit to this church even more interesting.

title.rendered: Sardara, Church of San Gregorio

content.rendered:
There are places where the sacred finds a way of making itself manifest in the enduring continuity of a faith cult, which defies time and cultures. This is the case of the church of San Gregorio. Located in the historic centre of Sardara, not far from the Nuragic sanctuary with a sacred well temple, near the church of Sant’Anastasia, a building of Byzantine origin, although its current layout dates back to the 15th century. 

The encounter with the church of San Gregorio gives us the opportunity to grasp one of the most refined manifestations of the dialogue between an emerging island Gothic, and Romanesque persistences, which marked the 14th century in Sardinia. 

We have no documentary evidence relating to the building of this church: its attribution to the first quarter of the 14th century is therefore the result of a purely stylistic analysis of the structure. 

The façade has a “gabled” profile, and is divided into three mirrors by bundled pilasters and two strong corner pilasters. The architraved portal, surmounted by an ogival arch and equipped with moulded jambs, is positioned in the central mirror. On the axis of the portal is the Gothic rose window surmounted by a series of small arches on corbels. Completing the façade is the bell gable with two narrow lights. A second portal with a pointed arch, opens on the northern side. 

The hall has a single nave with a wooden roof. The south-eastern apse has a semicircular profile on the inside and a square one on the outside: it is one of the manifestations of the architectural compromise between the strong Romanesque tradition, and the new Italian Gothic forms, which marks this church. In the apse, the presence of an archiacute double lancet window, in which traces of extensive restoration are legible, is worthy of note.

We leave this church with our eyes still enwrapped in its harmonious charm.

title.rendered: Santu Lussurgiu, Church of San Leonardo

content.rendered:
The history of mankind has always been associated with water, a precious vital element. It is no coincidence that human beings, since prehistoric times, have gone in search of springs and watercourses to choose the places in which to live. 

In Sardinia too, there are striking manifestations of this privileged relationship between human beings and water, and the church of San Leonardo bears explicit witness to this: the building was, in fact, constructed in the area called ‘delle sette fontane’, from the Spanish ‘siete fuentes’ because of the seven neighbouring springs. This relationship is also attested in many historical documents: in the ‘Condaghe di San Nicola di Trullas’ (12th-13th century) there is mention of a ‘villa VII funtanas’, in 1341 there is mention of an ‘ecclesia septem fontium (fonzium)’ and in 1355 there is evidence of the existence of the hospital of ‘San Leonardo di sette fontane’, run by the Ospedalieri di San Giovanni. 

The documentation does not attest to the date of construction of the church, made of basalt ashlars, but it seems more than plausible to place the construction of a first single-nave hall with a semicircular apse in the middle of the 12th century. Between the 13th and 14th centuries, the north wall was demolished and the apse was rebuilt with its present square plan and archaic single lancet window. The stylistic choice of the small monolithic arches is peculiar: they are rounded and not pointed like the apse single lancet window. 

The façade, surrounded by pilasters at the sides, is divided by round arches into two horizontal registers: the upper part is gabled, while the lower part, marked by the presence of two portals, architraved and with round lunettes, is in turn divided by a pilaster. 

The stylistic similarity of the two portals is not proof that they were made at the same time, but rather a reflection of the search for stylistic consistency on the part of those who made the second portal.

title.rendered: San Vero Milis, Church of Santa Sofia

content.rendered:
The ‘domo de sancte Eru’ (ancient name of San Vero Milis) is documented in several acts of the ‘Condàghe di S. Maria di Bonàrcado’ (12th-13th centuries), but no source provides explicit information on the Romanesque origin of the church. This origin can be deduced from the reading of a residual wall structure, which survived the radical renovation of the building in Renaissance forms, begun in the last twenty years of the 16th century and ended in 1604. The renovation was the work of Agostino Carchi from Genoa and Francesco Escano from Cagliari, as stated in the epigraph on the right-hand jamb of the triumphal arch. 

The head of the presbytery, located to the south-east, is in line with a section of the two-coloured right-angled face and with a similar portion of wall facing north-east.  Rows of medium-sized ashlars in sandstone and basalt rest on a straight scarp plinth, concluded by a cornice. 

The scarcity of the surviving masonry makes it difficult to specify the architectural nature of the structure in relation to the Romanesque building to which it belonged, but we can nevertheless attribute the two-coloured work of fine workmanship to the craftsmen active in the Kingdom of Arborea in the first quarter of the 13th century. 

The façade was made later, marked by a strong local eclectic tendency that combines Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque elements reinterpreted in a vernacular key with clear graphic-planar intentions. 

The single-nave, barrel-vaulted hall is divided into three large bays by rounded arches resting on Tuscan pilasters. Three chapels on each side of the nave are covered with lunette vaults: their unusual depth gives the building a great sense of space and luminosity. 

As we make our way towards the next stage of our journey, the dizzyingly swirling effect of the architectural style in which we have been immersed persists.

title.rendered: Porto Torres, Basilica di San Gavino

content.rendered:
Porto Torres is a city steeped in history: its foundation, with the name “Turris Libisonis”, dates back to the first century BC and the church of San Gavino, which we are about to visit, retains a very strong link with that historical moment. One of the most important archaeological areas is in fact a thermal complex known as ‘Palazzo di Re Barbaro’ (Palace of King Barbarian), named after the man who, according to hagiographic tradition, sent San Gavino, martyred at the time of Diocletian (304 A.D.), to his execution. 

Porto Torres was also an episcopal seat from 484 until 1441, when the bishop moved to Sassari. The Romanesque basilica of San Gavino can undoubtedly be counted as one of the most significant monuments of the Romanesque heritage of Sardinia. 

Archaeological investigations have established the existence of two older churches, both with a nave and two aisles, dating from the 5th to the 7th century. The smaller one is located under the northern flank of the Romanesque basilica, the other in the outer northern sector. 

We find the first attestation of the church of San Gavino in the ‘Condàghe di San Pietro di Silki’, dating from around 1082. Other information on the Romanesque basilica can be found in the ‘Condàghe di San Gavino’, a collection compiled in the 13th century. Despite this, the exact chronology of the building is not easy to determine, nor does the presence of two opposing apses, one on the north-east and the other on the south-west, one on each short side of the building, appear easy to explain: the façade is therefore missing and the entrances open on the long sides. 

The plan is longitudinal with three naves, divided by arcades on 22 bare columns and three pairs of cruciform pillars. To the north is the only surviving Romanesque portal, decorated with two human figures depicting Adam and Eve. The second portal, to the south, is from the 15th century, in Catalan Gothic style. 

The central nave has a wooden roof, while the side naves are cross-vaulted. 

The basilica is illuminated by single-lancet windows throughout the building. 

We say goodbye to this church, still fascinated by its sober grandeur.

title.rendered: Ploàghe, Church of St. Anthony of Salvénero

content.rendered:
Our relationship with the past is nourished by those traces of life capable of tenaciously resisting the wear and tear of time: memories handed down orally, written documents and material evidence, just like the church of Sant’Antonio di Salvénero. 

In fact the building, located a short distance from the Benedictine abbey of San Michele, is all that remains of the village of Salvénero, abandoned at the end of the 18th century. There are no documentary sources that provide information about this church, but its construction appears to be ascribable, for stylistic reasons, to the same workers who built the church of S. Maria di Òrria Pithinna (pizinna) (today Santa Maria Maddalena) in Chiaramonti and it could date back to the first quarter of the 13th century. 

The façade has an eyebrowed portal and a rectangular window of a later date, probably Aragonese. Small arches parallel to the sloping roofs, with a double thin row, are visible; those decorating the apse show a semicircular inner row, ogival on the outside. 

The hall is single-naved with a south-eastern apse. The façade and the apse have the characteristic two-colour pattern with alternating rows of limestone and red trachyte in medium-sized calcanerite stones.  In the apse there is a short single-light window on the axis, centred with a double splay. In the eastern wall, there is a cruciform window.

title.rendered: Ozieri, Church of Sant’Antioco di Bisarcio

content.rendered:
Romanesque churches show a privileged relationship with the landscape, which has always been intended as an integral part of the architectural project. The panoramic location of the church of Sant’Antioco di Bisarcio, in a dominant position on a hill about 20 km from the town of Ozieri, is an explicit confirmation of this characteristic. 

Built in local basalt, it is one of the largest Romanesque churches on the island. Its grandeur can be traced to its function as the cathedral of the diocese of Bisarcio, confirmed to date back by documented sources between 1065 and 1503. 

The present building appears to be the result of three construction phases: in the 11th century, the rows of slightly hewn calcarenite stones, visible at the base of the east side walls, were built; in the mid-12th century, the medium-sized, well-shaped calcarenite stones were created; and in the early 13th century, in the third building phase, a portico was added, which was rebuilt in the 16th century after a partial collapse.

The church has a three-nave floor plan and the apse is located to the east. The roof of the nave is made of wood, while that of the side aisles is made of cross vaults. The phytomorphic decorations on the capitals and bases of the columns, supporting the arches of the partitions, are of great visual and emotional impact. The apse, the work of masters of the Pisan school active in Sardinia in the mid-12th century, is divided into mirrors by half-columns with plant capitals and small arches with large bi-chrome lozenges. 

The ground floor of the portico has six bays with cross vaults supported by pillars with a cross section; the upper floor is divided into three barrel-vaulted rooms. The exterior is marked by three arches in the first order and by a series of small pointed arches in the second. We still have traces of the existence of the episcope in the right side parastas, due to the presence of ashlars in the walls of the area. 

While admiring this scenic and majestic church, we are also fascinated by the enchanting panorama that surrounds it.

title.rendered: Ottana, Church of San Nicola (Saint Nicholas)

content.rendered:
The Romanesque churches offer a plurality of ways into the history of Sardinia. 

 The name Ottana can be traced back perhaps to the Roman nobleman Ottius, which can be interpreted as deriving from the locution ‘(villa) Ottiana (estate or farm) of Ottio’, who was one of the great Roman landowners on the island.

 The church of San Nicola di Mira, set in a slightly elevated position above the town, dominates its surroundings with its straight lines and the harmony of its two delightfully contrasting colours, the delicate pink of the trachyte and the harsh black-purple of the basalt, which give it a unique and mysterious beauty. 

 Stratigraphic investigations have established the pre-existence of an early medieval church, possibly a monastery. An epigraph on parchment, preserved in a metal case found in the altar, informs us that the building was rebuilt on the occasion of its consecration by Bishop Zacharias. In a chronological phase that does not go beyond 1160, the church became the cathedral of the Ottana diocese until its suppression in the XVI century.

 The construction of the building took place in two phases, but can be traced back to a single design intention. The east-facing apse, transept and north side belong to the first phase, while the façade and south side belong to the second. The junction of the two construction phases can be seen on the south side, where the square bell tower was planned to be built, but which never took place. 

 The church has a “commissa” cross plan and the transept arms are barrel-vaulted.  The north arm of the transept is adorned with a painting, datable between 1339 and 1343, known as the ‘Ottana Altarpiece’. The portal is architraved, with a raised arch. 

 The façade, decorated with ceramic basins, is divided into three orders, with pilasters forming three large arches in the first two orders and a false loggia in the last one. 

 The single-nave hall with a wooden roof is lit by a mullioned window aligned with the portal. 

 Confident that the future will take care of this area, we bid farewell to this solemn Romanesque church.

title.rendered: Orotelli, Church of San Giovanni Battista (St. John Baptist)

content.rendered:
The meeting with the church of San Giovanni Battista gives us the opportunity to reflect on a phenomenon of which we are not always aware: in many Christian religious festivals it is possible to see the legacy of more ancient pagan rites. One example is the cult, one of the most practised in Sardinia, of St John the Baptist, protector of farmers and agriculture. His feast day is celebrated on 24th June, but the celebrations begin as early as 21st June with “is lampadas” or “is fogadonis”, the fires that date back to an ancient pagan ritual celebrating the Summer Solstice, and generally end on 29th June with the feast of Saints Peter and Paul. 

The church dedicated to San Giovanni Battista was built around 1116, to serve as a cathedral and temporary seat of the bishopric of Ottana, due to its temporary inability to function, and remained a vicar seat until 1139, when the ancient name of the village was still Ortillen.

The original structure, modified over the centuries, had a crux commissa plan and a single nave, with wooden roofing, while the arms of the transept had cross vaults. The side aisles, on the other hand, were added in the 1960s to increase the capacity of the hall. Of the original appearance, the façade has survived, divided into three parts, the apse and the corner pilasters of the transept and the sides. The architrave and lunette portal has an oculus in the centre surmounted by a series of small arches resting on moulded corbels, while the upper part of the sloping roof is decorated with small arches on corbels that continue along the sides of the building and along the apse elevation. 

In the apse, there is a single-light window with a sculpted Greek cross, similar to that of the church of San Nicola in Ottana. Other single lancet windows are present in the sides of the church. 

We say goodbye to the church of San Giovanni Battista with a last look of gratitude, for making us a little more aware of our origins.

title.rendered: Olbia, Basilica of San Simplicio

content.rendered:
The names of urban centres are significant historical symptoms of the past that generated them. However, their decoding is not always simple and unambiguous. This is particularly true of the city of Olbia: the name is Greek and means ‘happy’, which would suggest a remote but significant influence of Greek origin, but scholars are far from in agreement. This charming coastal town is now one of the most important urban centres in Sardinia, as Romanesque buildings such as the imposing Basilica of San Simplicio help to prove. 

In the absence of documentary sources attesting to the date of its foundation, the study of the building has nevertheless made it possible to identify five construction phases dating from before the 11th century to the second half of the 13th century.

The church has a floor plan with three naves divided by arcades on pillars and columns. The nave is covered by a wooden roof and closes with a west-north-west apse. The crowning of the pillars consists of thick abacuses in the shape of a truncated pyramid. One of the capitals is particularly noteworthy for its shape of rounded corners: this morphology is attested in the Po valley from the early Middle Ages onwards; the decorated ones have the general shape of an inverted truncated cone and two others are actually reused column bases.  

The façade is divided into two orders, the lower of which is in turn divided into three parts. One of the small arches to the south houses a marble tile depicting a scene with a knight and a long weapon, contrasting with an angel with a white weapon, a scene stylistically datable to the 7th century. 

The central part houses the portal with an architrave and an archway. In the upper order, off-axis from the portal, there is a triple lancet window. The decoration of the façade is enriched by the presence of eight ceramic basins.

We bid farewell to this building, still feeling immersed in its historical and architectural entanglements.

title.rendered: Morgongiòri, Church of Santa Sofia

content.rendered:
Places are custodians of memories and those who have lived in them leave traces of their passage, which translate into rituals of a profane or sacred nature. The ancient country church of Santa Sofia (Santa Assuìna or Santa Suìa, in Sardinian Language), preserves one of these memories: tradition has it that the church of Santa Sofia belonged to a medieval village that was attacked and destroyed by the Saracens in the first half of the 16th century. Those who escaped capture and massacre are said to have found refuge in the place where the village of Morgongiòri stands today. The festival dedicated to the Saint would have originated then and is renewed every year on the 15th and 16th of October. However, the church must certainly have been built before the final abandonment of the medieval settlement, at the beginning of the 16th century. 

The structure, with a double-pitched roof, is oriented longitudinally on the south-east/north-west axis, with the entrance facing north-west. On the main façade, supported by two small square-based pillars, there is a small portico protecting the entrance door to the church. At the apex of the slopes we see an iron cross and the double-sloped bell tower, surmounted by a small white stone cross and without bells. In the back wall and on the sides there are quadrangular openings that allow natural light to illuminate the interior of the church. 

A modern building with an elongated rectangular plan has been attached to the main body, probably used as a service room (civil or religious) during the feast of the saint. The building has undergone several rather invasive restorations, which compromise the reading of the original layout, the dating of which is not easily deducible. 

As we leave this place, we still seem to hear the voices of the souls who lived through the tragic events to which this building is so strongly linked.

title.rendered: Milis, Church of San Paolo (Saint Paul)

content.rendered:
One of the most fascinating characteristics of the Romanesque style is certainly the two-colour technique. It is no coincidence that the buildings constructed using this technique are among those that remain most easily impressed in the memory of those who have the opportunity to admire them. These include the splendid church of San Paolo, the first parish church of Milis, (before being replaced by the present one of San Sebastiano), already mentioned in the 12th-13th centuries in the ‘Condàghe di Santa Maria di Bonarcado’.

title.rendered: Macomèr, Church of the Madonna del Soccorso (Our Lady of Succor or Our Lady of Perpetual Help)

content.rendered:
Just like a beating heart, the history of many towns is made up of expansions and contractions, and it can be the case that some buildings, originally conceived to live far from the dynamics of the reference villages, end up over time being incorporated into them, changing, at least in part, their original connotation. This is the case of the church of the Madonna del Soccorso, one of the oldest in Macomèr, once located outside the town and now at the heart of the district from which the church takes its name. 

It is noteworthy that the church of Santa Maria served as a parish church before Macomèr was moved to a higher and safer location, i.e. on the rock where the castle stands, of which only a few remaining structures are now visible; it was here that the parish church of S. Pantaleo was later built. 

The building, made of blocks of greenish tuff and stylistically pertinent to the architectural panorama of Pisan Sardinia, dates back to the beginning of the 12th century. The original roof of the building, easily deducible from the reading of the façade, was a double-pitched roof with exposed beams.

The structure has a longitudinal plan with a single nave. The semicircular apse faces east and has a vaulted ceiling; the half-columns set on a shoe plinth divide it into mirrors on the outside. 

The church underwent two restorations, one in 1609 and the other in the early 1980s, which, with the addition of the sacristy and the obliteration of some parts of the building, modified the original structure.

title.rendered: Martis, Church of San Pantaleo (Saint Pantaleon)

content.rendered:
The vicissitudes of the Romanesque style in Sardinia are also linked to another stylistic current: that of the so-called “Italian Gothic”. This denomination is motivated by evidence: the persistence in Italy of a strong link with the building tradition consolidated in previous centuries (Romanesque, precisely), and the lack of appreciation for the vertical thrust characterising French architecture, the geographical area where Gothic originated.

 The church of San Pantaleo, whose toponym is documented from 1341 onwards, is precisely an eloquent example of Italian Gothic, which arrived in Sardinia before the Aragonese conquest of the island and the consequent spread of the Catalan Gothic style. In the absence of documentary information on its construction, we have relied on stylistic interpretation that has allowed us to place it in the first quarter of the 14th century. 

The building, made of limestone ashlars, has a floor plan with three cross-vaulted naves divided by pillars, with an oriented apse. At the front, there is a portal, above which there is a large oculus, once with a rose window, now lost. The tripartite façade shows the different elevation of the side aisles compared to the central one; corner pilasters delimit the central mirror, which are connected in the pediment with ogival trilobed arches that decorate the apex. 

As we walk away from the church, we give it one last farewell glance.

title.rendered: Ghilarza, Church of San Pietro di Zuri  (Saint Peter)

content.rendered:
There are monuments that seem to be destined to excel in history. This is how the church of San Pietro di Zuri appears to anyone who seeks to learn about the events which  have seen it as a protagonist. The last of these is a daring rescue operation: in the 1920s, the church and the entire village, which stood on the banks of the Tirso, were moved upstream, piece by piece, to avoid being submerged by the creation of the Lake Omodeo reservoir. Part of the ancient village rests underwater, but in dry periods it reappears, creating a very evocative effect.

The fame of the church of San Pietro is also justified by its grandeur, its colour given by the use of red andesite from the quarries of the Ghilarza plateau and another rare and particular element: an epigraph on the façade gives the date of its construction (1291), celebrates its builder (master Anselmo da Como) and passes on the name of the abbess Sardinia de Làcon, who commissioned it. 

The upper part of the façade is not the original one, but was rebuilt in 1504. At present, the lower part of the façade appears to be articulated in three parts by round-headed arches, adorned with a double torus molding and decorated on top. The portal is located in the central one. 

Aligned to the left of the façade is a large bell gable with a double row of archaic mullioned windows.

An original mullioned window – now lost, but the remains of which have been recovered – was replaced by a rectangular window in axis with the portal. 

Rebuilt by 1336, today the apse is dislocated to the north and has a semi-hexagonal plan and a hemispherical bowl roof. The hall is longitudinal with a wooden roof and the apse was originally semicircular and canonically oriented to the east. 

Inside, there is a trefoil niche whose right pillar originally belonged to the top of the original façade. 

A twisted frieze internally fills the lunette and jambs; the architraves and jambs are decorated with anthropomorphic and zoomorphic figures. 

As we leave this powerful and evocative church, we are aware of the privilege of having experienced a truly extraordinary encounter.

title.rendered: Galtellì, Chuch of San Pietro (Saint Peter)

content.rendered:
The history of the buildings is a sort of puzzle of architectural events that can only partially be traced back to a coherent unitary project. This is how the building complex, of which the church of San Pietro is an integral part, came into being. 

In fact, it consists of three buildings: the bell tower, built on the remains of an older tower, probably in the late 16th century; a Romanesque cathedral, unfinished but incorporated into the cemetery walls; a smaller church, possibly of early medieval origin, with a single nave but later enlarged to three naves with the reconstruction of the apse. The latter is also noteworthy for the presence of a cycle of frescoes dating back to the early 13th century, attributable to Umbro-Latium painters of the first decades of the 13th century, which were severely damaged during the renovation phases that led to the widening of the hall, and now fortunately partially readable again thanks to a recent restoration. 

The construction of the Romanesque cathedral of St. Peter, designed with a crux commissa plan, was started for the diocese of  “Galtellum”, plausibly around 1090: the small pre-existing church evidently did not seem suitable to accommodate the bishop’s chair. 

The work was never completed, being limited to the construction of the north side of the hall, the transept and the oriented apse, which was high enough to create a single-light window with a smooth splay. However, two bishop’s tombs were placed in the outer walls and the small existing church continued to accommodate the bishop’s activities. 

We salute this place with gratitude for the testimonies of life it has given us.

title.rendered: Gadóni, Church of Santa Maria Vergine Assunta (Saint Mary of the Assumption)

content.rendered:
If we were asked to summarise in a single word what effect the pervasive presence of Romanesque traces in Sardinia has on us, the natural choice would be the term “presidium”, because every church appears to be a place capable of carrying out simultaneously the functions of control, surveillance and defence of the faith. The parish church of Santa Maria Vergine Assunta, with its imposing bell tower, is one of these. 

It was built in the late Romanesque style in the 13th century. It has a high rectangular façade, with a fine pointed-arch wooden doorway in Aragonese Gothic style, surmounted by a circular rose window with stained glass. 

The back of the church is marked by the presence of the massive stone bell tower with a square bore, concluded by a golden dome with a cross and equipped with four semicircular single lancet windows in which the bells are placed. 

The single-nave plan was extended in 1303 with the addition of two side aisles, which include six chapels. Behind the altar, there are some painted panels of fine workmanship. 

The church has undergone many alterations, but the apse and portal are still the original ones. 

We bid goodbye to Gadoni, curious to know what the next stage of our journey has in store for us.

title.rendered: Cossoine, Church of Santa Maria Iscalas

content.rendered:
Sardinia is a land of strong contrasts: nature here still manifests itself in a primitive form, capable of arousing deep and intense emotions in those who venture there. Among the many peculiarities, the stones and rocks of this land, as well as framing the landscape, constitute a unique treasure that the Sardinians have been able to exploit since the dawn of civilisation. And the Romanesque churches are one of the most significant examples of their mastery of stonework. 

In the case of the church of Santa Maria Iscalas, the raw material used is white limestone, with fascinating chromatic shifts towards blue. The dating of this building is uncertain: scholars’ opinions vary between the 6th-7th and 10th-11th centuries.

The masonry technique adopted is very interesting: large-sized ashlars are interlocked to form the corners, while in the intermediate wall sections we see the use of superimposed freshly worked ashlars, now bound with mortar but originally built using the dry technique. 

It has a free cross plan, with the arms of the cross ending in straight walls, except for the east elevation which ends in an apse with a small cross-shaped window. The connection between the barrel-vaulted arms is provided by a lantern covered by a pyramidal roof. In a second building phase, a rectangular structure with an east-facing apse was added to the cruciform plan in the west, with a splayed single lancet window with plain splays in the centre. At the point where the arms intersect, the hemispherical dome rises, which, unusually for the island, does not emerge from the tiburium and is only visible from the inside. 

Inside the church there are traces of medieval wall paintings.

We salute this special building with fulfilled curiosity, While we wait to discover the next jewel in the mosaic of the island’s Romanesque buildings.

title.rendered: Càbras, Church of San Giovanni di Sinis

content.rendered:
The location of the church of San Giovanni di Sinis corresponds to a part of the ancient necropolis of the Phoenician-Punic city of Tharros. The discovery of a circular epigraphic funerary table is eloquent evidence of the continuing relationship between the site and its cemetery function, even in the Middle Ages. 

The three-nave building that has come down to us, dates back to the Proto-Romanesque period (11th century), but it is the result of a metamorphosis of a pre-existing Byzantine church with an inscribed cross plan, datable to the 6th-7th century, of which the domed body and transversal arms have survived, where mullioned windows were opened during the Proto-Romanesque renovation. The central cube is raised above the side volumes; the transept is surmounted by a dome and closed off to the east by the apse. A barrel vault was originally set at a lower level than the present one, created during the renovation of the building. The Byzantine dome shows the great skill of the craftsmen who made it: the square structure was connected to the circular dome by the construction of pendentives, an architectural solution that shows the influence of Constantinople in the training of the craftsmen involved in this project. 

Leaving the church of San Giovanni di Sinis, it is difficult to forget the scent of the sea that surrounds it.

The discovery of a circular epigraphic funerary table is eloquent evidence of the continuing relationship between the site and its cemetery function, even in the Middle Ages. 

The three-nave building that has come down to us, dates back to the Proto-Romanesque period (11th century), but it is the result of a metamorphosis of a pre-existing Byzantine church with an inscribed cross plan, datable to the 6th-7th century, of which the domed body and transversal arms have survived, where mullioned windows were opened during the Proto-Romanesque renovation.

The central cube is raised above the side volumes; the transept is surmounted by a dome and closed off to the east by the apse.

A barrel vault was originally set at a lower level than the present one, created during the renovation of the building.

The Byzantine dome shows the great skill of the craftsmen who made it: the square structure was connected to the circular dome by the construction of pendentives, an architectural solution that shows the influence of Constantinople in the training of the craftsmen involved in this project. 

Leaving the church of San Giovanni di Sinis, it is difficult to forget the scent of the sea that surrounds it.

title.rendered: Bauladu, Church of San Gregorio Magno (Saint Gregory the Great)

content.rendered:
Forty-one of the more than eight hundred letters that make up the epistolary of Pope Gregory I, also known as Gregory the Great, concern Sardinia in some way. Written between 590 and 604, the dates of the beginning and end of his pontificate, they represent a precious documentary source for the historical knowledge of the island’s early Middle Ages. 

The churches dedicated to the cult of St Gregory the Great are therefore of great interest in this regard. Among these, the parish church of San Gregorio Magno in Bauladu should be counted. The first documents in which the Church of San Gregorio Magno is mentioned are some cards of the “Condàghe di Santa Maria di Bonarcado”: the n.37 of 1205, which records the donation of the Camaldolese of the properties of “Thomas de Madrona”, some of which are in the territory of Bauladu, in which neither the Villa nor the priory of San Gregorio is mentioned; and the n.173 of 1228, in which, instead, a prior of Bauladu is mentioned. 

The construction can therefore be placed with certainty between these two dates. After its construction, the church underwent various modifications: inside, the different styles of the different interventions are clearly visible. The original structure consisted of a single-nave hall. 

The portal is surmounted by a late 16th-century Catalan-Gothic limestone relief of great artistic interest, representing the Virgin and Child between two angels. This work has had a strong effect on the collective imagination: in fact, the popular belief has been consolidated by this relief being made by the legendary three “Damas Cugurras“, ladies and artists known at the time, from the village of Santa Barbara di Turre. 

Another valuable artistic element in the church is the statue of the Madonna della Neve (Our Lady of the Snow): made of polychrome wood, it is probably of the Spanish school and dates from the 16th century. 

We also bid farewell to this church with devotion, as we head towards a new meeting.

title.rendered: Ardara, Church of Santa Maria del Regno (Saint Mary of the Kingdom)

content.rendered:
There are buildings that, due to their landscape location, seem to act as real sentinels: bulwarks placed to protect the surrounding territory, precious reference points for all those who live in or pass through those territories. 

The church of Santa Maria del Regno is one of these “sentinels”, and it is no coincidence that it was originally connected to the nearby Judicial castle of Ardara, seat of the Judges of Torres, of which only a few sections of the walls now remain. 

This church, one of the best known and most significant of Sardinian Romanesque, was a ‘palatine chapel’, i.e. belonging to a ruling family and not to the Catholic Church. Santa Maria del Regno was in fact owned by the Giudici of Torres, and ceremonies and coronations were held there. The consecration epigraph on the high altar attests that construction of the building began in the 11th century and was completed in 1107. 

The church, which is both imposing and essential, has three naves. The façade, divided into five mirrors by pilasters, has a portal with a raised arch and a mullioned window. The square bell tower, now incomplete due to various collapses, is leaning against the north side of the structure. The interior is marked by cylindrical pillars supporting the arches, on which a series of panels depicting a saint or an apostle were placed in the 17th century. The side naves are covered by cross vaults, while the central one has a wooden roof. The apse houses the Retablo Maggiore of Ardara, a polyptych from the early 16th century. 

Austerity and power: this is the gift we take away with us as we bid goodbye to this church.

title.rendered: Oschiri, Chiesa di Nostra Signora di Castro (Our Lady of Castro)

content.rendered:
The church of Nostra Signora di Castro owes its name to its proximity to the remains of a Roman fort, called ‘castrum’ in Latin, which then became the toponym ‘Castro’ given to the church and the diocese of which it was the cathedral in the Middle Ages, despite its small size. It should be borne in mind that, in the Middle Ages, the function of a cathedral could also be attributed to small buildings, just like this one. 

The church was built in the middle of the 12th century. The façade is surrounded by powerful corner pilasters and is articulated by two thin pilasters connected by small arches in groups of three, next to which there are two semi-columns. 

The hall has a single-nave plan and its wooden roof was made by repeating the square module based on the width of the hall itself. The interior lighting is provided by double splayed single-lancet windows opening in the sides and apse, and by cruciform openings in the apse pediment and in the façade.

title.rendered: Ittiri, Chiesa di San Leonardo (St. Leonard)

content.rendered:
Among archaeology enthusiasts, the story of the relocation of the colossal Egyptian temple of Abu Simbel, around 1960, at risk of flooding due to the construction of the Aswan Dam, is widely known. That operation has rightly become a milestone in the history of world archaeology. What is perhaps less well known, is that in Sardinia too, we have important examples of this courageous and daring practice. 

One of these is represented by two Romanesque churches: San Pietro di Zuri, and San Leonardo, which we are now dealing with. Following the construction of the Cuga Dam in the mid-20th century and the consequent creation of the reservoir, the church of San Leonardo, with the remaining perimeter walls and what remained of the apse, was dismantled and rebuilt further upstream. 

The construction of this church – also known as ‘San Leonardo di Cuga’ – should be placed in the second half of the 12th century.  It was attached to a monastery and was part of the villa of Cuga or Tuta, in the Curatoria of Coros, belonging to the Judicial Kingdom of Torres, as attested by documents dated 1341 that show the payment of tithes. A stone inscription – currently kept in the church of San Leonardo in Villanova Monteleone – gives us news of a restoration dated 1538, by Bernardo Simon, baron of Ittiri and Uri.

Today, the building has a longitudinal plan with an oriented semicircular apse and a roof supported by wooden trusses. The façade faces west and is divided into three mirrors by two pilasters, the central one concluded by a pair of small arches and the lateral ones by a blind arch; the two sides of the building are decorated with ten large arches supported, two by two, by long and flattened pilasters starting from a low plinth. The interior lighting is provided by two pairs of single-lancet windows opening on the sides; in the apse there was another window, obliterated during the restoration.

title.rendered: Fordongianus, Church of San Lussorio

content.rendered:
The term ‘hagiography’, refers to the set of testimonies that contribute to defining the memory of the lives of saints and the cults they are honoured with: written texts, images, epigraphs and monuments. Many of the Romanesque churches in Sardinia belong to this category of evidence, and the church of San Lussorio is a significant example: on the south side of the building we find, still walled in, an inscription referring to the ‘Passio Sancti Luxurii’. It seems likely that the association of this place with the ‘passion’ of St Lussorio was already active in the 4th century and that the cult was practised in a semi-hypogeum environment – the so-called ‘crypt’ – originally intended for funerary functions or for a different and older cult. 

The construction of the Romanesque church of St Lussorio, under whose floor the remains of the Byzantine building can be found, dates back to the beginning of the 12th century. From the original construction phase, the building appears to have had a single-nave, barrel-vaulted ground plan with an eastern apse. 

A small apse was added to the west side of this room and the north side was enlarged with a square room, intended to house the saint’s funeral monument, which included an earthen grave that was believed to be the martyr’s tomb. A U-shaped ambulatory (or walkway) was then built around Lussorio’s tomb, allowing pilgrims to move around the core of the holy site. In the late Vandal or early Byzantine period, the sanctuary was enlarged, with the addition of an apsidal room and an altar. 

In the first half of the 7th century, the building must have undergone a phase of abandonment and consequent ruin, only to be subsequently renovated with the construction of a new worship hall, equipped with a baptismal font, probably associated with a small baptistery. 

The Catalan-Gothic portal on the façade testifies to its construction during the Aragonese period. Between 1250 and 1270, the church was rebuilt due to the collapse of the original roof and the south wall, and a wooden roof replaced the previous stone one. Today, wall sections on the north side and the apse are evidence of the original layout.
