title.rendered: Codrongianos, Church of the Santissima Trinità di Saccargia (Holy Trinity of Saccargia)

content.rendered:
If we were asked to name just one building capable of representing in the collective imagination, the iconic symbol of Romanesque architecture in Sardinia, the choice would fall on the church of the Santissima Trinità di Saccargia. There are many reasons for this success: the fortunate location of the building in the landscape, its imposing dimensions, combined with a refined stylistic and aesthetic care in the use of two-tone colours, and the presence, in the apse, of one of the rare Sardinian examples of Romanesque frescoes. From 1112, the abbey of Saccargia became part of the Sardinian possessions of the Camaldolese monks. 

The two-colour technique that characterises the building is the work of Pisan-Pistoia trained workers, active in the second half of the 12th century. 

Only a few sections of the original cloister and monastery walls remain today, visible to the south of the building. The plan of the church is in the shape of a ‘commissa’ cross and the transept has three apses to the north-east, belonging to the first building phase (late 11th and early 12th century), covered with cross vaults. The façade has a portico and the majestic bell tower and sacristy stand out to the south of the main building. 

The hall was originally intended to be shorter than the present one, but was later raised and lengthened towards the west, giving the building a new façade in three orders. In this second construction phase, the portico, bell tower and sacristy were also built. 

Restoration work in the 19th century subsequently altered the original appearance of the church.

title.rendered: Chiaramonti, Church of Santa Maria Maddalena (Saint Mary Magdalene)

content.rendered:
The search for dialogue between architectural creations and the landscape is one of the constants of the Romanesque style.  A notable example is the church of Santa Maria Maddalena, built shortly after 1205, when the Turritan noblewoman Maria de Zori donated the title of ‘sancta Maria de Orria pithinna’ to the Camaldolese abbey of San Salvatore. 

The church was built in two stages, with the use of two different workers, one of whom was an expert in the two-colour technique, visible in several sections of the masonry. The building has a “commissa” cross plan, obtained by adding two chapels at a later stage. 

The façade has a walled ashlar with an inscription documenting building work carried out in 1335. The portal is centred. The arms of the transept have an independent entrance on the west side and a single-light window at the eastern end. 

The hall has a single nave, with an original wooden roof that was later transformed into a barrel vault (similar to the arms of the transept), and the apse is oriented to the south-east. Below the slopes of the two gables are a series of flush-cut monolithic limestone arches, each set on a pediment. The hall is also lit by a single-lancet window on each side, ribbed with a double splay like the one in the centre of the apse half-cylinder.

The building has a "commissa" cross plan, obtained by adding two chapels at a later stage. 

The façade has a walled ashlar with an inscription documenting building work carried out in 1335.

The portal is centred. The arms of the transept have an independent entrance on the west side and a single-light window at the eastern end. 

The hall has a single nave, with an original wooden roof that was later transformed into a barrel vault (similar to the arms of the transept), and the apse is oriented to the south-east.

Below the slopes of the two gables are a series of flush-cut monolithic limestone arches, each set on a pediment.

The hall is also lit by a single-lancet window on each side, ribbed with a double splay like the one in the centre of the apse half-cylinder.

title.rendered: Cargeghe, Church of Santa Maria ‘e Contra (Saint Mary)

content.rendered:
Linguistics teach us that the boundaries of a word can be expanded to become a wide and articulate discourse, but also that a large text can be expressed in a single word. This also applies to architectural styles, which are veritable codes of expression. We can, in fact, conceive every building as a text, capable of conveying discourse that can be expanded into imposing and complex architectural forms or contracted into simple and essential buildings. 

The church of Santa Maria ‘e Contra is one of the examples of this quest for architectural essentiality. It is no coincidence that it is considered the smallest Romanesque church in Sardinia. It is a country church that was a dependency of the basilica of Saccargia and we find the title ‘Sancte Mariae in Contra’ mentioned from 1125 among the Sardinian possessions of San Salvatore di Camàldoli. 

The church, made of medium-sized limestone blocks, has a single-nave plan, with an oriented apse. Formal analysis of the building suggests the use of workers from the nearby curatories of Ploaghe and Goceano, active around the second half of the 12th century, and the construction of the church should therefore date back to this period. 

The façade, with a bell gable, features a portal made with jambs in monolithic blocks and surmounted by a drainage arch raised by one ashlar. Two corbels, still in their original position, must have supported a canopy or a wooden portico above the same portal, which have now disappeared. Two small cruciform windows open one in the eastern elevation, the other above the apse. On the sides and in the apse there are single lancet windows with double splay and ogival ribs.

title.rendered: Bulzi, Church of San Pietro del Crocefisso (Saint Peter of the Crucifix)

content.rendered:
Not infrequently, it occurs that history transforms some sacred buildings into real treasure chests, guardians of precious works of art. This is the case of the Church of San Pietro del Crocefisso, known by the eloquent denomination of “Lu Rughifissu’, ‘of the Crucifix’ and ‘of the Images’: this church has in fact hosted the 13th-century wooden group of the Deposition, now in the parish church of San Sebastiano di Bulzi, and an 18th-century pictorial polyptych, the ‘Retablo de las Imagines’. 

We do not have any documents attesting to the date of construction, but we can date the end of the work thanks to an inscription, painted on a wooden roof beam, of ‘Iohannes’ bishop of Ampurias in the first half of the 13th century. We can therefore place the creation of the church in the first twenty years of the 12th century, while an enlargement of the building must be placed in the last quarter of the same century. A new roof was finally built between 1200 and 1225. 

The building has a ‘commissa’ cross plan. The façade, the apsidal space and the interior of the transept show the characteristic two-colour pattern, created by alternating limestone and basalt ashlars. 

The front part, divided into three orders, hosts the architraved portal, with monolithic jambs, capitals with water leaves and cauliculi, and a smooth architrave surmounted by a lunette, decorated with a relief representing a person in a praying position, flanked by two bearded men.

title.rendered: Bosa, Church of San Pietro Extra Muros

content.rendered:
In ancient times, many Romanesque churches in Sardinia served as cathedrals. Studying their history can therefore allow us to retrace a significant part of the historical events of the island’s dioceses. The church of San Pietro was also, from 1073, the cathedral and seat of the diocese of Bosa, which was suppressed in the early 16th century. 

The building stands in the rural locality of Calamedia, already populated since Phoenician-Punic and Roman times, and owes its name ‘extra muros’ to the progressive displacement of the settlement towards the foot of the castle of Bosa. It is one of the oldest examples of Sardinian Romanesque, although unfortunately a heavy and invasive restoration, carried out in 1938, led to the replacement of most of the original stones. A pilaster ashlar, now tampered with, bears an inscription by Sisinnio Etra – it is not entirely clear whether he was the client or the builder – with the date 1062, referring to the start of construction. 

The work was completed in 1073, as attested by another inscription, also present in the church, of Bishop Constantine de Castra. The hall has three naves and ends with an apse, rebuilt in the 12th century, to the east.  The façade was built at the beginning of the 13th century and has three large pointed arches. The portal occupies the central arch, with an architrave bordered at the top by a twisted arch and carved in a mock loggia, whose small arches are decorated with the Virgin and Child and the Emperor Constantine between two trees, and on the outer sides with Saints Peter and Paul.

An aedicule with knotted columns is located at the top, in an axis with the portal and the oculus. The intertwined arches and the aedicule with intertwined columns are matched by only one other sacral building: the church of St. Peter in Zuri (1291), which was built by the architect Anselmo da Como. This leads to the hypothesis that the reconstruction of the upper part of the facade of San Pietro di Bosa at the end of the 13th century, is also attributable to this architect.

The central nave – the one that preserves the only traces of the original 11th-century layout – has a wooden roof, while the side aisles have a cross vault. The partitions are made up of arches resting on rectangular pillars. The slopes are decorated with intertwined arches.

title.rendered: Borutta, Church of San Pietro di Sòrres

content.rendered:
History is made up of relationships: between human beings, places, objects and buildings.  It happens that some of these, for various reasons, rise to the role of emblems of an era, a style, a culture. These are the characteristics of the church of San Pietro di Sorres, one of the most famous in Sardinia, perhaps because of its proximity to the 131 state road – the ‘Carlo Felice’ – the main road that still today follows the ancient Roman road linking the north and south of the island. 

Certainly, the fact that the church was the cathedral of the diocese of Sorres from 1112 to 1503 must have also contributed to its fame. Since there are no documents to prove the date of its construction, we have to resort to formal analysis to date it. It is thus possible to identify two building phases: one from the second half of the 11th century, to which some rows to the south and east of the building belong, and the other from the second half of the 12th century, characterised by the bisoma technique and the decidedly marked decorative style. 

During the settlement of a Benedictine monastic community, new buildings in neo-Romanesque style were added to the surviving structures of the rectory between 1953 and 1955, of which a few rooms remain, spared by the reconstruction. There are also a few documents left of the old rectory, such as a description, an approximate plan and a survey prior to the reconstruction.

The two-colour effect, also used in the construction of the load-bearing structures, is given by the use of limestone ashlars. The limestone and basalt ashlars came from the nearby quarries of Torralba.

The hall has a cross-vaulted nave and two aisles made of basalt. It is worth noting the presence of a plùteo with inlaid wheels, datable between the end of the 12th and the beginning of the 13th century.

title.rendered: Bidonì, Church of San Pietro (Saint Peter)

content.rendered:
What we call art, is the most explicit expression of the aesthetic care that has characterised our way of being in the world, since the dawn of humanity. At times, this aesthetic propensity has taken the path of magnificence; in other cases, however, it is the essential simplicity that guides the hand of craftsmen, artists and architects. This is the case of St Peter’s Church, characterised by an extreme formal essentiality. 

A document, datable to the beginning of the 12th century, offers the oldest mention of this church, i.e. the act by which the Arborean judge Constantine I de Lacon-Serra founded the Camaldolese monastery of Santa Maria di Bonarcado, and among the churches entrusted to him, we find this one mentioned. Already in the second half of the 12th century, the building was the object of a reconstruction, perhaps to be associated with the donation of the curtis of Bidonì to the Catalan Agalbursa de Bas, who in 1157 married the judge of Arborea Barisone I de Lacon-Serra, later King of Sardinia. 

The well-crafted stones used in the construction provide an effective chromatic effect, with shades ranging from red to pale yellow. The façade is marked by a portal surmounted by an architrave and a lunette, and presents – engraved on a ashlar placed on the left – the graphic scheme of a church, surrounded by another larger one: it is perhaps the ‘seal’ of belonging of the ‘domo’ of S. Pietro to the abbey of Bonarcado. Another portal, now walled up, originally opened on the south side of the church, also characterised by the presence of two single-lancet windows. 

The only exceptions to the extreme decorative sobriety of the church are the eyebrow carved on the cornice at the top of the single lancet window of the apse and the series of round arches set on decorated corbels that crown the apse just below the roof.

The single-nave, timber-roofed hall has an east-facing apse, in axis with the building, marked by the presence of a single-light window.

title.rendered: Masullas, Church of S. Leonardo (Saint Leonard)

content.rendered:
Like palimpsests – those ancient manuscripts on papyrus or parchment whose original text has been erased to be replaced by another -, many buildings conceal a secret and stratified nature, such as the church of San Leonardo.

Its oldest soul came to light during the restoration of 1977: that work revealed the presence of the foundation course of a pre-existing single-nave church, which served as the basis for the structure of the Romanesque church, built in the first half of the 12th century, determining the direction of its axis and the position of the apse.

The façade, surmounted by a bell gable, is divided into two parts by a faux loggia bordered by double-arched arches and a scarp that is interrupted at the two half-columns. The first level houses the portal with a semi-circular lunette, the second level is marked by the presence of a succession of double-arched hanging arches, supported by corbels, and the third level features a central mullioned window.

The material used to construct the building is varied: sandstone and trachyte for the two main elevations and mixed material on the sides.

title.rendered: Usellus, Church of Santa Lucia (Saint Lucy)

content.rendered:
While it is often the urban centres of the island that oﬀer travellers monumental examples of Romanesque architecture, it is not infrequent in the countryside to have the opportunity to encounter sacred buildings structurally closer to the original phases of this architectural and cultural phenomenon. One example is the country church of Santa Lucia.

There is no documentary evidence to date the moment of its construction, which can be inferred from the formal analysis of the building as lying between the end of the 12th and the first half of the 13th century.

The church has a single nave, to which a rectangular building was added at an uncertain time, probably to replace the original apse. The façade, with a double-sloping top, hosts the architraved portal, equipped with jambs and corbels; on the architrave rest the outlet arch and the round lunette. The corbel on the left is decorated with an anthropomorphic protome, while the one on the right is badly damaged.

The façade culminates in a bell gable in which the two lights of the semi-circular rib are separated by a small column with a crutch capital. A small rectangular opening opens at the south-eastern head, while another portal with an arched rib opens on the south-western elevation. Near the base of one of the monolithic jambs, we can see an ashlar with a semi-circular cavity, probably intended to hold a ceramic basin, of which no traces survive. The roof of the interior space, divided into two rooms by a low arch, is made of wood and has been built recently. The eighteenth-century altar, in masonry and stucco, holds the statue of the saint to whom the church is dedicated.

The church has a single nave, to which a rectangular building was added at an uncertain time, probably to replace the original apse.

The façade, with a double-sloping top, hosts the architraved portal, equipped with jambs and corbels; on the architrave rest the outlet arch and the round lunette.

The corbel on the left is decorated with an anthropomorphic protome, while the one on the right is badly damaged.

The façade culminates in a bell gable in which the two lights of the semi-circular rib are separated by a small column with a crutch capital.

A small rectangular opening opens at the south-eastern head, while another portal with an arched rib opens on the south-western elevation.

Near the base of one of the monolithic jambs, we can see an ashlar with a semi-circular cavity, probably intended to hold a ceramic basin, of which no traces survive.

The roof of the interior space, divided into two rooms by a low arch, is made of wood and has been built recently.

The eighteenth-century altar, in masonry and stucco, holds the statue of the saint to whom the church is dedicated.

title.rendered: Oristano, Church of the Maddalena di Silì

content.rendered:
Despite the fact that cultural mechanisms tend to be wary of the phenomena of change, to the point of relegating them to anomalies or exceptions to the system, the concrete cultural life of every community is made up of incessant changes and continuous, though often imperceptible, mutations. It is with this idea in mind that we must observe the manifestations of cultural ‘contamination’ between architectural styles, to which even Romanesque churches bear witness. An example of this is the Church of the Maddalena di Silì, cited for the coexistence of stylistic elements belonging to the Italian Gothic style and others traceable to the Romanesque tradition.

The church was first mentioned in 1336, and its construction seems to date back to the 14th century. The building has a single-nave plan and was built using volcanic rock and limestone ashlars. The hall has a wooden roof; the apse is square and has a ribbed cross-vaulted roof. On the outside, only the façade and the east-facing apse remain legible as elements of the original phase, due to the fact that a later monastery was built against the church. The façade is divided into three parts by the presence of two corner pilasters and two pilasters surmounted by small hanging arches. The portal, located in the centre of the façade, is architraved and surmounted by a ribbed arch, and has capitals with plant motifs. The south side of the façade has undergone extensive restoration and is now articulated with six mirrors surmounted by small hanging arches. In the third mirror of the façade, there is another architraved portal. The apse oﬀers the room two sources of light: a single-lancet window and a large three-foiled mullioned window.

title.rendered: Lunamatrona, Church of Santa Maria Assunta (Saint Mary of the Assumption)

content.rendered:
Sometimes, there are places that seem to be born to respond to the particular need to reveal, and at the same time protect, the memory of the sacred.

This is the case of the medieval compendium of Lunamatrona, whose origin presumably dates back to between the 12th and 13th centuries, and of which the church of Santa Maria Assunta is an integral part, together with the churches of San Sebastiano and the parish church of San Giovanni Battista. The church of Santa Maria Assunta was the first parish of the village until 1630, and then took on the function of a cemetery church. As for the chronology of the church’s construction, we have an important dating element: one of the original church bells bears the date ‘1326’, so it is at least conceivable that it was built at the beginning of the 14thcentury.

The church, which has been extensively renovated, now has an essential façade, crowned by a bell gable. The portal is archivolted with a round arch made of ashlars decorated with ﬂoral motifs, stylistically with an Arab atmosphere; next to it, two concavities, intended to hold the typical ceramic basins, are visible. The hall has a single nave and is now devoid of any decorative elements.

title.rendered: Usellus, Church of Santa Reparata

content.rendered:
Man-made places not infrequently preserve and hand down memories of the men and women who have found refuge and sustenance there over the centuries. The continuity of life is in fact a significant trend in human geography, even if it is marked by the changing functions of the places and the communities that occupy them. One example is the church of Santa Reparata, built in limestone around the middle of the 12th century in the vicinity of decaying structures from the Roman era.

Noteworthy is the mention, in the Condaghe di Santa Maria di Bonarcado, of a bishop of Ušellus, called Rellu or Murrellu, who participated in the consecration of the church of Santa Maria di Bonarcado itself, in 1146. The building, an interesting example of rural island architecture, has a façade with a horizontal crenellated crowning and a bell gable, as well as a porticoed enclosure. In spite of the radical renovations carried out at the end of the 18th century, the original Romanesque layout with three naves and an east-facing apse is still legible. Inside, the building still preserves the stone slab ﬂooring, the base rows of the perimeter walls and the foundations of the partitions, all of them pertaining to the original construction phase.

title.rendered: Villamar, Church of San Pietro (Saint Peter)

content.rendered:
The church of San Pietro was first recorded in a document dated 29 October 1206 that came down to us from a 16th-century copy, which in turn transcribed an earlier copy dated 1307. However, we have no direct information on its construction, although we can place it in the second half of the 13th century: the south aisle seems to belong to this original phase.

The north aisle is smaller, including the size of the apse, and was built not long afterwards. The two naves are divided by three wide arcades supported by rectangular pillars. The façade is completed by an imposing bell gable. The structure rests on a wall plinth, from which corner pilasters and pilasters articulate the walls in mirrors.

Noteworthy are the decorations that animate the elongated corbels: we recognise motifs of human protomes, geometric grids, ﬂowers, leaves, crosses, steps, moulded sections, listels and shells.

title.rendered: Ussana, Church of San Saturnino

content.rendered:
Sacred places and their names can oﬀer, to those who are interested in them, precious evidence or simple suggestions about the links between territories, the relations between urban centres, or the connections between communities. This is the case of the church of San Saturnino, dedicated to the martyr from Cagliari, known locally as ‘Santu Sadurru’.

Its first mention appears in a manuscript from 1581, which identifies it as the ancient parish church. The structure, most likely built in the first quarter of the 12th century, was erected with materials of various cuts and sizes and has a plan with two naves and apses facing north-east, each with a curved portal. The two naves are divided by irregular arcades, resting on re-use columns and capitals dating from the first century AD. The north aisle has a barrel-vaulted roof with corbelled arches.

A collapse of the south stone vault in the 13th century was the trigger for the building to undergo several reconstructions: the reinforcement of the north-east wall, the reconstruction of the south-west wall and the replacement of the collapsed stone vault with a new wooden one. Also significant is the displacement of the altar, and the consequent reversal of the liturgical axis, dating back to 1700.

The recent history of the church also provides important evidence: documentary sources reveal that the church was used in 1917 as accommodation for prisoners of war.

title.rendered: Samassi, Church of San Gemiliano

content.rendered:
If, at times, it is the complexity of the architecture that attracts us to the style of an ancient building, the disarming power of simplicity can be just as surprising.

The art of Sardinian Romanesque churches often oﬀers us this suggestion, and the church of San Gemiliano is a particularly explicit example. This old church belonged (at least since 1118) to the Camaldolese monastery of San Mamiliano on the island of Montecristo in Tuscany. We have no documents attesting to the date of its construction, though we can presumably place it in the 13th century.

A noteworthy element is the fact that the church stands on a pre-existing Byzantine chamber tomb. In the Romanesque masonry, the presence of reused materials can be detected in particular fragments of small Byzantine pillars originally belonging to a presbytery enclosure.

The single-nave hall has a wooden roof. The sides and façade are marked by pilasters, while corner pilasters contribute to the solid visual impact of the entire structure. The portal opening onto the façade, architraved and resting on two phytomorphic capitals, shows a drainage arch, in turn set on two corbels worked with human features. The sides of the structure are decorated with several single-light windows. A final, important mention should be made of the presence, inside the church, of the funerary marble monument dedicated to Emanuele Castelvì, the work of the sculptor Scipione Aprile in 1586.

title.rendered: Gesico, Church of Santa Maria d’Itria

content.rendered:
The study of the past inevitably feeds on clues and fragments of memory. Each element can thus become precious for the historian, who is committed to painting a picture of knowledge that can oﬀer an image, never exhaustive but at least scientifically plausible, of the portion of the past examined.

The cult of the Madonna d’Itria, venerated in numerous localities in Sardinia, is one of these clues. It is, in fact, a cult linked to the Greek-Oriental religious tradition, and every church with this dedication is a direct testimony to the cultural heritage bequeathed by more than six centuries of Byzantine domination of Sardinia. The same applies to our church of Santa Maria d’Itria in Gesico, whose construction seems to date back to the 13thcentury, as documented in sources dating back to 1215, which also mention it as the village’s first parish church.

It is a single-nave building, with a presbytery raised one step above the ﬂoor of the hall and a semi–circular apse. Today, the side walls are plastered and painted, but originally the ashlars used in the construction were left exposed. The façade, which originally had a bell gable with a bronze bell – later removed – is modulated in three parts by pilasters on either side of the entrance portal, surmounted by an architrave engraved with the date 1305. The side elevations are enlivened by a series of small hanging arches resting on corbels. The rear part is characterised by the presence of a semi–circular apse with a small single-light window splayed inwards. The upper part of the apse has a series of rounded hanging arches resting on decorative corbels.

title.rendered: Santa Giusta, Church of Santa Giusta (Saint Justa of Cagliari)

content.rendered:
Sometimes it happens that history takes care of some monuments, preserving them from the decay time reserves for most of the things in the world, so that they can rise to the status of symbolic icons of the culture that generated them: the Church of Santa Giusta is one of these monuments, one of the most significant specimens of Romanesque architecture not only in Sardinia, but also in the wider panorama that extends beyond the borders of the island.

This magnificent church is dedicated to Saint Justa of Cagliari who, according to tradition, was martyred here in 130 at the time of the Roman emperor Diocletian. 

It served as the cathedral of the diocese of the same name (between the second half of the 11th century and the 16th century); nevertheless, no document attests the date of construction, plausibly dating back to the 12th century.

The raw material of the original, not reused, structures is sandstone. The external wall faces are extremely refined and original and strongly projecting pilasters, connected by large arches, mark the sides of the church. On the façade, there is a splendid sculpture representing a lion and a lioness pouncing on a deer and two pilasters that connect in a large arch with a trifora (a three-part window). 

The interior space, overlooking a crypt located under the presbytery (“where – according to Alberto La Marmora – it is believed that Saint Justa suffered martyrdom”), is divided into three naves by columns surmounted by reused capitals – a phenomenon widely attested in Romanesque churches – datable to Roman times.

The beauty of this building is such that not even a detailed description could do this architectural gem justice. There is only one solution left: enjoy live viewing.

title.rendered: Pula, Church of Sant’Efisio Martire di Nora (Saint Ephysius Martyr of Nora)

content.rendered:
Collective identities feed on individual memories. The memory of history translates them into culture. These identities require constant maintenance and care, entrusted to specific custodians: people, rituals, objects, places. This old church in Nora – the ancient city of Phoenician origin, then Punic and finally Roman – is one of these custodians: small and located by the sea, was built in the early Middle Ages in the necropolis area pertaining to the Phoenician-Punic city, in the place where tradition identifies the martyrdom of this Saint.

In 1089, Costantine Salùsio II de Lacon Gunàle, Judge (King) of the Judicate, or Judgedom (Sardinian Medieval Kingdoms) of Calari (today Cagliari), gave the title, and therefore the ownership, of this place to the Benedictine monks of the Abbey of Saint-Victor from Marseille. The sanctuary was then rebuilt in an early Romanesque style, reusing limestone and sandstone blocks as building material. 

The domed structure and the crypt located in the presbytery area are seemingly attributable to this original building phase. Today the church has a three-nave plan, covered with barrel vaults resting on sub-arches, while, to the south east, the apse is without windows. Originally, the Romanesque facade was forward, almost aligned with the bell tower, but between the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries it was modified to add a porticoed atrium.

For Sardinian people, Saint Ephysius is the guardian of the collective identity of the island, capable of placating – at least once a year – conflicts and parochial divisions. Since 1657, every 1st of May the statue of the saint (made in the 17th century) leaves his church situated in Cagliari’s old town and sets off in procession towards Nora, where it usually stays until the morning of May the 4th and then returns to its main sacred temple.

title.rendered: Dolianova, Church of San Pantaleo (Saint Pantaleon)

content.rendered:
The church of Saint Pantaleo in Dolianova, one of the most important architectural creations of the Middle Ages in Sardinia, is a striking example of Romanesque art and has its roots in an early Christian past. The discovery of a baptismal font with a hemispherical basin, dated between the 5th  and 6th centuries, and a marble pillar decorated with interwoven ribbon and phytomorphic spirals, coming from a mid-Byzantine iconostasis of the second half of the 10th century, are testimony to this past.  A clear evidence of the existence of a diocese is dated 1089, with the ascension to the chair of the first bishop named Virgilius.

The construction of the church began in 1170 with the use of tuff stone of local origin, while the completion of the works took place in different phases between 1261 and 1289. The planimetric layout with three naves – which has remained unchanged until today – and the construction of the cross pillars and part of the walls date back to that time. The only apse is to the south-east, decorated with frescoes; the roof is made of wood, even if the original project included stone vaults.

The decorations on the corbels of the arches are very suggestive, with phytomorphic, anthropomorphic, zoomorphic and fantasy subjects, such as monstrous and geometric figures. The lintel of the entrance portal is a reused Roman marble, decorated with snakes between the canes in relief. 

Inside we can admire the remarkable capitals decorated with scenes from the New Testament as well as one, already in the Gothic style, with leaves aligned in a “crochet” pattern. Finally, the “Retablo di San Pantaleo”, built between the end of the 15th century and the beginning of the 16th century, is worthy of note.

title.rendered: Gùspini, Church of Santa Maria di Malta (St. Mary of Malta)

content.rendered:
All of the Romanesque churches in Sardinia are a dense and effective network in which each church represents a precious knot, but even the smallest churches fully belong to this broad system of strongly interconnected religious buildings.

This fully applies also to the church of Santa Maria di Gùspini, a building that can be dated, in its original layout, to the thirteenth century. Only the facade of the original construction survives, while the current hall dates back to the 18th century. The opinion of some scholars deserves to be mentioned: according to them, the church belonged to the Knights of the Order of Malta, whose presence in Gùspini is ascertained in the sixteenth century. The decoration of the architrave in the side portal of the façade, with an eight-pointed cross – the so-called Maltese cross -, can be read as a significant clue in favor of this thesis. The Maltese Cross was in fact officially adopted by the Order of the Hospitaller Knights of St. John in 1126.

The floor plan of the building currently has three naves, with arches resting on square pillars. The semi-circular apse faces east and has a wooden roof.  The facade of the building, only partially preserved in its original aspect, shows the brow portal in the center, under a large window, and a series of arches, above which the presence of ashlars with the traditional housing for ceramic basins is discernible. 

Noteworthy is the presence of a wooden statue representing the sleeping Assumption.

title.rendered: Iglesias, Cathedral Church of Santa Chiara of Assisi (Saint Clare)

content.rendered:
The Cathedral Church of Santa Chiara of Assisi, the patron saint of the city of Iglesias, was built between 1284 and 1288 at the behest of Ugolino della Gherardesca, Count of Donoratico, famous for having been mentioned by Dante Alighieri in his Divine Comedy. This is one of the very few cathedral churches dedicated to the Saint of Assisi who was canonized in 1255.

The façade, divided into two orders by a horizontal, moulded cornice, is a vestige of the original Romanesque building. In the first order, we have a portal with architrave, while in the second one there is an oculus enclosed within two windows with a Gothic profile, now walled up. The terminal part has a pitched roof with Gothic arches.

On the right side of the façade, the bell tower stands with four ancient bronzes, among which the one made by the Pisan Andrea di Guidotto, between 1337 and 1338, stands out in terms of size. 

During the Aragonese period, the city’s name changed from “Villa di Chiesa” to Iglesias. The church of Santa Chiara became a cathedral in 1503 at the behest of Pope Julius II Della Rovere. 

In order to adapt this building to the new role of center of spiritual irradiation for the whole territory, numerous adjustments were necessary. Those of late Gothic taste began in the course of the sixteenth century and involved the construction of a new vast presbytery, the construction of a new roof with rib vaults equipped with a boss, and a projecting stone at the intersection of the ribs of the vault, carved with the figures of the most venerated saints in the diocese. The adjustments continued with the construction of four side rooms serving as confraternity chapels. 

Thenceforth, the cult of Saint Antiochus of Sulcis, an early Christian martyr and patron saint of the former local diocese of the ancient city of Sulci, was introduced in Iglesias. Today, the island and the ancient town of Sant’Antioco, in the South-west archipelago, are named after him. 

At the beginning of the seventeenth century, the cult of Saint Antiochus was further strengthened following the discovery of his remains inside the catacombs of Sulci, which was then depopulated and threatened by raids from Barbary pirates. The remains of this Saint were therefore saved and brought to Santa Chiara’s to be preserved and venerated for more than two centuries. 

On the left of the main altar, a special domed chapel was built, still preserved today. Dominated by a majestic golden wooden altar from the first twenty years of the eighteenth century, it is now further embellished by the presence of a simulacrum of Antiochus, from the same period. During the nineteenth century, a large chapel was finally built, mirroring that of the Saint, and the religious building accordingly reached its current Latin cross plan.

title.rendered: Tratalìas, Santa Maria Church (Virgin Mary of Montserrat Church)

content.rendered:
At the beginning of the new millennium, the bishops of the ancient city of Sulci (today Sant’Antioco), threatened by Saracen raids, found shelter in the backcountry, a few kilometers from the southwestern coast of the Sulcis region. In this village, in around 1213, they built the church of Santa Maria to become the new cathedral of the diocese and the reference for all the faithful of the area. 

This church, entitled to the cult of the Virgin Mary of Monserrat, with its beautiful Romanesque lines, stands out imposingly even today among the small houses of the ancient village of Tratalìas, now abandoned. The Virgin of Montserrat (or Our Lady of Montserrat), Patroness of Catalonia, is a statue of a black Madonna venerated in a monastery on the Montserrat Mountain, in Catalonia. According to an ancient Iberian tradition, during the Catalan-Aragonese period, the worship of the Virgin Mary of Montserrat was brought to this area and never faded since. It endured even when the Sulcitan bishops decided to leave this village, which had become unsafe since the 14th century, to move to the fortified city of Villa Di Chiesa (today Iglesias) and, consequently, this church was no longer a cathedral. The venerated Marian simulacrum that was kept in Tratalìas was then taken to the unassailable medieval city but, in order not to lose the link with the ancient village, once a year, at least from the 15th century, the statue of the Virgin from Iglesias returns to her old church, escorted by the devout people in an evocative procession to celebrate a ritual feast. Surviving from the original layout of this picturesque settlement are a small number of houses, which have today been restructured.

This former cathedral, made of local stone, has a façade with two rows of Lombard bands, two lozenges and a polylobed rose window. The building is softened by decorative motifs in the shape of a curved leaf that recur in its most salient features: on the façade, for example, they adorn the arch that surmounts the entrance portal and they surround the rose window, while they embellish the numerous shelves supporting the blind arcades along the entire building rest. The façade stands as a unicum in the island’s Romanesque architectural landscape due to the floating staircase that reaches the roofs from an opening in the tympanum. The side portals are also remarkable, in particular the one positioned to the north, which has the architrave decorated with two lions in relief, placed frontally. The interior has a rectangular plan with a nave and two aisles, with round arches set on pillars and ends in a semi-circular apse. The roof consists in wooden trusses.

The local school retable, kept in this church since 1596, also speaks of this profound Marian faith of the inhabitants of Sulcis. The pictorial compartments of this work are composed around the central theme of the Madonna enthroned, framed on the sides by the figures of St. John the Baptist and St. John the Evangelist, while at the bottom stands Saint Antiochus of Sulci, Patron Saint of the diocese of Iglesias.

title.rendered: Uta, Church of Santa Maria (St. Mary’s Church)

content.rendered:
Immersed in the countryside, albeit not far from the inhabited center, the church of Santa Maria shows itself to our austere gaze. What immediately strikes the visitor is the strong structural similarity of this building with the 13th century church of Santa Maria di Tratalìas. In the absence of documentary sources that inform us on the date of construction of this church, this similarity allows us to place its construction in the thirteenth century.

The church is built with sedimentary stone. Originally, the building had a floor plan with two naves, and then moved on to three. The aisles, with wooden roofs, are divided by round arches and set on columns with phytomorphic capitals, all contemporary to the construction of the church.

The third capital on the left as you enter the hall is an exception, which appears to be clearly reused and dates back to Roman times, just as the capital reused as a holy water stoup must be attributed to the same period. 

The façade is divided into two orders and its apse faces east. The lower order is divided into three mirrors, the central one of which houses the architraved portal, with a brow-shaped unloading arch, decorated with twines and set on two corbels with lions. The second order houses the pediment with a mullioned window. The façade is then completed by a bell gable, built at a later time.

The lateral decorations depicting the episodes of the Gospel are still perfectly legible and offer us an eloquent example of a widespread practice in the Middle Ages: the use of these images to facilitate the preaching, addressed to a multitude of mostly illiterate faithful.

title.rendered: Villa San Pietro, Church of San Pietro

content.rendered:
The Church of San Pietro in Villa San Pietro offers a precious testimony of the widespread diffusion of the Romanesque style in Sardinia.

Even in the absence of explicit documentary data referable to the time of construction of this building, we can place its construction in the thirteenth century.

One of the most interesting elements we can detect in this edifice is the contamination between the stylistic features properly pertinent to the Romanesque style with some that instead recall the Gothic style, then in the process of asserting itself. It is a phenomenon – slow and gradual yet decisive at the same time – typical of the epoch.

The church was built using limestone ashlars. It has a single nave plan closed by an apse on the axis and is completed by a wooden roof.

The internal space is articulated by spans characterized by rounded diaphragm arches.

As a demonstration of the mixture with the Gothic, the external facade has a bell gable and is divided into three mirrors ending with pointed arches, set on variously decorated corbels.

Also visible on the façade are the hemispherical cavities that must have been used to house a series of ceramic basins that have since been lost.

The side elevations also have a division into mirrors similar to that of the facade, but here the arches are round, therefore in line with the underlying Romanesque style.

In addition to the main portal of the facade, there is a second one, located on the north side, with a grey stone architrave decorated with a cross and a human figure. The pointed arches in the façade of the apse are in Gothic style.

title.rendered: Villamassargia, Church of San Ranieri (Saint Rainerius)

content.rendered:
At the end of the 13th century, the small village of Villamassargia became, for a short time, the seat of that small fiefdom that Bonifacio della Gherardesca, Count of Donoratico, bestowed on himself in southwestern Sardinia. In this flourishing agricultural and mining center, he established a new church to be both an identity symbol for the local community and an emblem of that recent link between his new territory and the Republic of Pisa, to which his dynasty was inextricably linked, being the Gherardeschi, or della Gherardesca, one of the most prominent Pisan families.

As we can read from an epigraph in Latin, closed in a lozenge placed on the facade, the church was built by the master Arzocco di Garnas in 1307 and was dedicated to Saint Rainerius, Patron Saint of Pisa. Over time, the building was surrounded by houses and even today it fits with its churchyard in the heart of the village as a unifying element of the urban fabric, lending material and spiritual continuity to a historical and religious bond that has lasted for over seven hundred years. Over such a long period of time, this church has witnessed all the events of the community and its ups and downs. Following the end of the Pisan glory in Sardinia, and the consequent ushering in of the Catalan-Aragonese and Spanish period, many new Iberian cults arrived on the island. One of these was the Veneration of Our Lady of the Pillar, coming from the city of Zaragoza in Aragon, to which this church was rededicated in order to suppress Pisan memories and unite, in the name of common cults, the people of the vast domains of Spain, since she is the Patroness of the Hispanic peoples.

The entire facade of the medieval church still bears the testimony of the Romanesque lines already turning to Gothic, made of shaped ashlars of local stone, adorned with a few but elegant decorative elements. Curved and fleshy leaves surround the entrance portal and the central rose window, while the biblical figures of Eve and the tempting serpent stand out among the plants of the garden of Eden that adorn the horizontal frame above the entrance. The current internal structure dates back to the period from the fifteenth to the seventeenth centuries. It includes a seventeenth-century barrel-vaulted hall and a cross-vaulted main chapel, which is accessed via a Gothic arch in well-shaped stone ashlars and soberly softened by capitals in a pure Iberian style. The stoup at the entrance is inspired by the same artistic sensitivity, with its basin decorated with fish reliefs.

title.rendered: Villaspeciosa, Church of San Platano

content.rendered:
The church of San Platano in Villaspeciosa shows a great example of reuse, one of the most typical phenomena of the ancient world.  Indeed, for the construction of this building, presumably attributable to the twelfth century, many reuse materials – especially marble – from Roman sites were employed. This edifice, built with limestone building material, is impressive in the Sardinian Romanesque panorama for its uncommon architectural shape, having a plan with two naves, both with apses and covered by round arches that rest on reused Roman columns, whose capitals are visible at the top of the columns. Originally, the naves probably had a barrel vault, destroyed by a collapse in the 15th century, and it was then replaced with a wooden roof. The facade is divided into three mirrors: the two side ones have a curved portal with inlaid crosses; in the central one, there is a reused marble slab decorated with an interwoven frame and four-petaled flowers and a single-lancet window with interlacing decorated marble cèntina enriched with decorated clypeus. The housings for two ceramic basins and two partially preserved inlaid wheels are still visible. 

This area is also renowned, from an archaeological point of view, for the presence of the Roman mosaic of Saint Chromatius, which, with its 160 square meters, is the largest found so far in Sardinia. It is moreover no coincidence that it is situated not very far from the church: the proximity between the two sites is a clear example of how the past can feed the present, to translate into the future.
